div.p: In this note we study stability properties of linear timeinvariant delay systems given in state-space form. We consider specifically the notion of asymptotic stability independent of delay. Systems with both commensurate and noncommensurate delays are investigated. We present for each class of systems a necessary and sufficient condition in terms of structured singular values, and further we demonstrate how these conditions may be extended to study stability independent of delay for uncertain systems. Our results consist of several frequency sweeping tests that can be systematically implemented and that should complement the previous work.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Stability problems for time-delay systems have been a topic of longstanding interest; the monographs [ 121 and [20] record extensive studies on these problems. A specific notion conceming stability of delay systems is asymptotic stability independent of delay. This notion was formally introduced in, e.g., [IS], and has received considerable research interest in the past decade. Roughly, a timedelay system is said to be asymptotically stable independent of delay if that system maintains stability with respect to all nonnegative delay parameters.

The earlier development on asymptotic stability independent of delay has led to many useful results, particularly for linear timeinvariant systems with commensurate delays. Noteworthy are the so-called two-variable criterion developed in [17] and [18] and its subsequent modifications in [5] and [ll]. The two-variable criterion was initially deemed both necessary and sufficient for asymptotic stability independent of delay, but later was found in [19] to be only sufficient, so are the criteria in [5] and [ll]. More recently, improved stability tests based on the two-variable criterion have also been reported in [SI,[9], [14], [15], and [26], and these tests provide necessary and sufficient conditions. Briefly, the tests of [8], [9], and [14] require that a polynomial be generated first from two bivariate polynomials and that its roots be solved next. The step of generating the polynomial, however, may be a difficult task for high-order systems with many delays, and there seems to be no systematic procedure for performing this task. On the other hand, the test of [ 151 requires the use of a bilinear transformation and then testing the stability of a delay-free polynomial, whose coefficients, however, depend on a real parameter. A Routh-Hurwitz test was suggested in [15] to accomplish this step, which requires generating and solving a sequence of polynomials (i.e., polynomials forming the first column of the Routh-Hunvitz table). Likewise, for systems with many delays, difficulty may also arise in generating a parameterdependent Routh-Hurwitz table. Moreover, the criterion in [26] requires a somewhat complicated recursive procedure. To summarize, though these criteria can be effectively tested for low-order systems, their implementation, as noted in [26], may encounter a varying degree of difficulty for high-order systems, for which algebraic techniques become less effective and numerical computations play a more important role.

In this note we consider asymptotic stability independent of delay for both commensurate and noncommensurate delay systems. Our approach is motivated by the current research in robust stability analysis. This approach proves both natural and fruitful for studying asymptotic stability independent of delay. Indeed, in an inexact sense, asymptotic stability independent of delay may itself be interpreted as a robust stability problem. Our development leads to several necessary and sufficient conditions that possess the form of typical small gain conditions in robust stability analysis. An important robust stability measure known as the structured singular value [lo], [24] is used to quantify these conditions. As such, these conditions may be tested rather efficiently using the well-developed computational methods [23] and softwares [l] in robust stability analysis. Furthermore, since they are small gain conditions, these results may provide a useful starting point for studying both stability and stabilization problems for uncertain systems independent of delay.

Our results differ from and complement the previous work in two aspects. First, we consider delay systems given in state-space form, unlike in the previous work which almost always involves returning, at some point, to an analysis of systems in the form of a scalar differential-difference equation, or a bivariate polynomial. The statespace formulation is slightly more general than that of a two-variable polynomial. Furthermore, though it is always possible to transform the former class of systems to the latter ones, such transformations will necessarily result in a significant level of computational complexity. Our approach avoids completely such complexity. Secondly, our results provide a systematic, computation-oriented frequency sweeping test that is particularly amenable to numerical implementation. This ease of implementation makes it suitable for analyzing systems with high dimensions and many delays. It is worth noting that frequency sweeping tests have become standard tools in robust control theory and are generally considered to be effective (see, e.g., [2] and [23]).

In comparison, the earlier tests require more or less analysis "by hand" or symbolic computations and may be difficult to implement for systems with high orders and multiple delays. As a final remark, it is also useful to point out that for systems of noncommensurate delays, our results may provide only de facto sufficient conditions since the exact computation of the structured singular value is difficult. This difficulty becomes even more serious when the system under consideration is uncertain, as one then needs to compute a structured singular value with respect to real and complex uncertainties. This problem is known to be difficult [4].
Partial results in this paper have been previously presented in [6].

This computation, however, is even more difficult than that required in Theorem 3.2, due to the presence of real uncertainties. Indeed, it is known [4] that the problem of computing structured singular values with respect to real and complex uncertainties is in general NP-hard. As such, the main utility of Theorem 4.1 lies in that it provides an analysis tool and a potentially nonconservative sufficient condition which can be obtained by computing an upper bound of the structured singular value.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this note we have studied stability properties of linear timeinvariant delay systems. A main feature about our results is that they can be systematically implemented; indeed, stated in terms of structured singular values, these conditions may be checked by making use of the well-documented softwares developed for robustness analysis in general and for structured singular value analysis in particular (see, e.g., [l]). This is especially the case for systems with commensurate delays, for which our test amounts to computing the spectral radius of a frequency dependent matrix. For systems of noncommensurate delays, the computation becomes harder but a possibly nonconservative sufficient condition can be obtained readily by computing an upper bound of the structured singular value.
